US automakers are struggling.
High gas prices have dampened the SUV market.
GM and Ford both have had the investment status of their bonds downgraded.
Each continues to lose market share to Japanese and other foreign carmakers.
American automakers need to reverse these trends and soon if they hope to survive.
One way to do that is to come up with cars that create their own buzz, and for Ford the path to better days starts at a massive test track in Dearborn, Michigan.

We came here to meet the man Ford hopes will steer the company toward greater success in the future by reaching back to honor classic design from the past.
Hau Thai-Tang is the designer in charge of freshening the look and feel of Ford's longest-selling brand, the Mustang.
(Soundbite of door closing)
So I'll take you out just on the track, so you have a better sense of what we do.
Tang took us for a spin in a sparking 2005, Windveil blue, metallic Ford Mustang.

Redesigning the Mustang would be a plum assignment for almost any designer.
For Tang, it seemed like destiny.
He was five years old when he spotted his first Mustang in war-torn Vietnam.
The Mustang had been shipped to Saigon as part of a program to boost morale for US troops.
It certainly got Hau Thai-Tang's blood pumping.
It was a white Mach 1 Mustang brought over as part of a goodwill tour to promote safe driving with the US troops in Vietnam.
It really left a lasting impression on me, with a long wheel base, a long hood line, very muscular.
It reinforced all those positive images of America.
It was big, it was powerful, and it really stood for freedom.
In 1975, Tang's family escaped Saigon and moved to New York City.
There, Tang excelled in school, especially math.
After college he got a job as an engineer with Ford and bought his first car, a Mustang, of course.
Now he's director of Ford's special vehicle team, where he oversees the automaker's performance line of cars and trucks, the vehicles built with speed and style in mind.

Hau Thai-Tang shared some of the secrets of successful car design, the details that help explain why some cars have near-universal appeal, the so-called `neck-craning quotient,' and the small tweaks that make drivers feel instantly comfortable as they settle behind the wheel.
It's something all designers strive for, but not all cars hit that mark.
With his tailored suit and his elegant demeanor, Hau Thai-Tang doesn't fit the picture of a motorhead behind the wheel of a hot rod.
But he's totally comfortable behind the wheel of a Mustang.
He knows the car inside and out.
Every nut, bolt and curve required his scrutiny and his final approval.
And he needed to move the design forward and yet make sure that at first glance everyone would immediately know the car was a Mustang.
In design parlance, he said he achieved this by focusing on so-called `heritage cues.'
That's our terminology.
There are some certainly classic Mustang design cues that make the car instantly recognizable as a Mustang.
It starts with the proportions: the long hood, the very long wheel base, the short deck.
So all of those things we refer to as heritage cues 'cause they make the car instantly recognizable as a Mustang.

Another part of his mission and his challenge was to create a car with great sex appeal, that would seduce buyers who fell in love with the car when it hit the streets in the early '60s--in other words, a sleek vehicle for buyers who were no longer as sleek or as slim as they were years ago, the automotive equivalent of loose-fitting jeans.
So the seats are naturally roomier.
The seat belts are positioned to accommodate an abundant waistline.
And while the Mustang still has the silhouette of a sports car, the frame has been lifted to help ease the strain on aging knees and hips when drivers step into and out of the car.
Even the sound of the engine, that low roar, was carefully calibrated to tap into a potential buyer's memory bank.
